stem: A 52-year-old client has been receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) for 6 weeks following bowel surgery. Based on the documentation in the Liver Function & TPN Surveillance Log, which finding indicates the development of TPN-Associated Liver Disease (PNALD)?

tabs.title: Liver Enzyme Trends
tabs.content:
TestResult (Week 1)Result (Week 6)
Conjugated Bilirubin0.2 mg/dL4.2 mg/dL (High)
Alkaline Phosphatase64 U/L420 U/L (High)
ALT / AST24 / 28158 / 142 (High)
Serum Albumin3.4 g/dL2.8 g/dL (Low)

tabs.title: Nursing Assessment
tabs.content: Current: Sclera are ikteric (jaundiced). Client reports 'itching' all over the body (pruritus). Abdominal ultrasound shows gallbladder sludge and hepatic steatosis (fatty liver). Stools are light-colored (acholic).

tabs.title: Nutrition Log
tabs.content:
TPN Formulation: High-fat emulsion; 20% lipids given daily.
Calories: 2,800 kcal/day (Hypercaloric).

options.text: The combination of high conjugated bilirubin (4.2) and acholic stools
The increase in ALT and AST enzymes
The high lipid content of the TPN

rationale.correct: Long-term TPN use can cause **Cholestasis and Liver Disease (a1)**. The most specific lab indicator is the rise in **conjugated bilirubin** (4.2), which along with high alkaline phosphatase and 'acholic' (light-colored) stools, indicates that bile flow is obstructed or has ceased (cholestasis). Constant 'overfeeding' with carbohydrates and lipids causes the liver to accumulate fat (steatosis) and become inflamed, eventually leading to fibrosis if the TPN is not adjusted or cycled.
clinicalPearls: Early sign: Sludge in the gallbladder. Definitive sign: Jaundice/High conjugated bili.
Cycle TPN (e.g., 12 hours on/12 off) to give the liver a 'rest' and reduce the risk of disease.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Lipids are the *cause* or 'risk factor,' but the 'indicator of disease' is the physiological outcome (Bilirubun/Jaundice).

mnemonic.title: TPN-Yellow
mnemonic.expansion: Too much fat. Too long on the bag. Bilirubin rises. Eyes turn yellow.
